head.title: New TV Season in Review; When Parenthood Takes A Sitcom Beating

hedline.hl1: New TV Season in Review; When Parenthood Takes A Sitcom Beating

abstract.p: William McDonald reviews premiere of new CBS comedy series Yes, Dear (M)

block.p: The title of this new sitcom might suggest the usual cliched treatment of a tired old married couple. In fact what we have here is a generic treatment of two tired young couples.
The title of this new sitcom might suggest the usual cliched treatment of a tired old married couple. In fact what we have here is a generic treatment of two tired young couples.

Greg and Kim Warner (Anthony Clark and Jean Louisa Kelly) are frazzled suburbanites coping with first-time parenthood. Greg has the added job of coping with Kim, a stay-at-home mom who obsesses about doing all the right things for 1-year-old Sam, as prescribed in the latest child-development books. (''Mommy doesn't want you to grow up to have food issues,'' defenseless little Sam is told between spoonfuls.)

The aim is to spoof today's anxious, competitive, humorless culture of child rearing. That's a promising idea, but good satire requires wit and some bite, and little is evident in tonight's pilot episode.

As yin to Greg and Kim's yang is a second pair of standard types: Kim's sexually bored sister, Christine (Liza Snyder), and Christine's do-nothing husband, Jimmy (Mike O'Malley), a couple with two children and a laissez-faire policy toward them. As the freeloading brother-in-law, Mr. O'Malley gets in a few good one-liners, but he's also a mouthpiece for obvious, juvenile humor.
Next week it's about breast feeding. One can guess what to expect when it's potty-training time.
